page.title: 11ORCHID FIELDS
page.content: Close to our village there are several hay meadows.These fields are relics of a bygone age,having by various means survived much as they were in the 19th Century.No artificial fertilizers or sprays have been used on them.The old ridge and furrows are still clearly visible.The furrows are often full of water late into the Spring.Grazed in the winter then left undisturbed until late in the summer for haymaking, these meadows contain a rich variety of plant life including green veined, common spotted,frog and marsh orchids. Cowslips,meadow-thistle,milkwort,salad burnett,dyers greenweed and field scabious all abound.Marbled white, meadow brown,gatekeeper and speckled wood butterflies all visit the flowers. In early Spring the haunting cry of the curlew can be heard and snipe may often be flushed from the damp meadows.
